item.title: [HADOOP-16700] RpcQueueTime may be negative when the response has to be sent later
item.description: RpcQueueTime may be negative when the response has to be sent later.
item.summary: RpcQueueTime may be negative when the response has to be sent later

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: cgregori xkrogen please have a look, thanks.

This message was automatically generated.
Hi xuzq_zander, can you more fully describe the issue? What causes the queue time to be negative? Under what situations does this occur?

Thanks xkrogen.
newCall(timestamp1) > enQueue > inQueue > (timestamp2)handler > processing > response(timestamp3) > updateMetric.

 

Like above, QueueTime is computed in updateMetric, and QueueTime = timestamp2 - call.timestamp(timestamp1) - enQueueTime.  

But call.timestamp maybe changed in sendResponse, so QueueTime = timestamp2 - call.timestamp(timestamp3) - enQueueTime, it will be negative.

// processResponse
//
// If we were unable to write the entire response out, then 
// insert in Selector queue. 
//
call.connection.responseQueue.addFirst(call);

if (inHandler) {
  // set the serve time when the response has to be sent later
  call.timestampNanos = Time.monotonicNowNanos();
  
  incPending();
  try {
    // Wakeup the thread blocked on select, only then can the call 
    // to channel.register() complete.
    writeSelector.wakeup();
    channel.register(writeSelector, SelectionKey.OP_WRITE, call);
  } catch (ClosedChannelException e) {
    //Its ok. channel might be closed else where.
    done = true;
  } finally {
    decPending();
  }
}

Thanks for the explanation xuzq_zander! Very helpful. It definitely seems like a valid issue.

I took a look at the v001 patch. By the way, please follow the patch naming conventions – it should be HADOOP-16700.001.patch (period instead of hyphen before the version, and you don't need to specify a branch when it is trunk).

The general approach seems sound to me. I am concerned about all of the changes you've made to the signatures of methods, removing receiveTime. First off Server is a public interface, so we should not make breaking changes to its API. To introduce a new method here, you need to keep the old one but mark it as @Deprecated. Second off, this change seems unrelated to this JIRA? If that is the case, we should keep it separate.

My only other comment is that we should update the comments here within Call:

    long timestampNanos;         // time received when response is null
                                 // time served when response is not null
    long responseTimestampNanos;

I think that it would now be more accurate to say:

    long timestampNanos;         // time the call was received
    long responseTimestampNanos; // time the call was served

Let me know if you think that isn't correct.
Thanks xkrogen for the comment, it's very helpful for me,  please review HADOOP-16700.002.patch

-1 overall

The checkstyle issues are because of the fields not being private, but this fits with how Call is used overall. I am +1 on the new patch.

I just committed this to trunk. Thanks for the contribution xuzq_zander!

SUCCESS: Integrated in Jenkins build Hadoop-trunk-Commit #17674 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/Hadoop-trunk-Commit/17674/)
HADOOP-16700. Track response time separately in Server.Call to avoid (xkrogen: rev be77231452baee2c3dd68f7c0991411cae2eea1b)

  • (edit) hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/ipc/Server.java
Just a heads up I also backported this down to branch-2.10, to get all of the version with HADOOP-16266 present.
Removing 2.11.0 fix version after branch-2 -> branch-2.10 rename
